pros: I cannot say too much positive about working at the Cerebral Palsy Association in Alberta.  What I can say positive is seeing the member of the association come in from day-to-day and thrive with their care workers.  From educational programs to social interaction the Association is blessed to have a facility like they have.
cons: I will not insult this association as this will make me no better than them.  I will however state while working with this organization I saw first hand how the upper management work and treat their employees.  I would like to think the main purpose of a charity is to assist the members or public with this disability.  Not the case.  The only thing that the management is looking at is for their own families.  3 out of 4 higher management all have children that have this disability.  They are so closely connected that they do not see anything other than what is in their bubble.  For employees that do not have children or a family member with the disability they are irrelivent and eventually shunned.

review_title: The people driving the bus dont have a license
pros: You love what your doing cause you are actively improving the quality of life for people with disabilities.  You have the opportunity to see on a daily basis how your efforts are helping out people who are far less fortunate.
cons: The directors of the association (not all but most) are leading in circles.  With no clear direction and no true leadership capabilities they are clearly in the position they have not based upon their education or experience, but solely because they are profiting off their own children's disability.  I had never seen so little communication, topped with a "What can this charity do for me" mentality.  Maybe its naive of me to feel a charity should be focused on its "clients" but here it is sadly not the case.  Those in power are not qualified to be there, it is disappointing to watch how little they do, and how much they take.
